content.description:
A long buttress/ridge. The first half is easy but bushy climbing, and then it steepens above a notch., Finish up cracks and grooves to the upper North Ridge. Not considered an amazing climb by the FA party.



Begin down and right of the Steinbok/Ibex col and climb the crest of the ridge/buttress.

Standard rack to 4"

climbs.name: Northwest route
climbs.fa: FRA Asgar Bentzen, Hamish Mutch, Bob & Glenn Woodsworth 1962

content.description:
From the north col, climb just right of the ridge crest up cracks and short walls to summit. Easy to get into 4th or low 5th class climbing with poor route finding.



Gain the bowl northwest of the peak either via a bushwack up the drainage from the south or from Chamois Peak by a traverse along the intervening ridge 

n/a

climbs.name: Proof is in the Pudding
climbs.fa: Dwayne Barg, Drew Brayshaw, Shaun Neufeld July 2003

content.description:
P1: climb a right/trending crack and corner to a belay behind a large detached block (45 m, 10a).

P2: continue up the ramp, which thins and becomes a roof. From its right end, step right on face holds to a cruxy thin crack. Belay on a ledge (30 m, 10c)

P3: a long pitch. Start up a short awkward offwidth to gain a left-trending diagonal crack which is followed across the face. (55 m, 10b)

p4: Move left off ledge, easy at first, then stem up a right-facing, right-leaning corner and pull over a roof at its top. Continue up easier ledges to a belay ledge (50m ,10a)

p5,6: Can be done as one long pitch or split in two. Climb flakes and a short corner to a higher ledge (25 m). Step down and right and climb a prominent right-leaning diagonal hand crack to the summit ridge (35 m 5.9).



Begin about 200 m left of the southeast col. See topo

Full rack to 4"

Climb the obvious ridge from the col to the summit. There are a few bushy ledges but most of the climbing is enjoyably clean up corners and slabs.

Start on the left up slabs (5.6), climb to roofs (5.9), pass first roof on the left then move right, passing another roof, to reach the ridge crest (5.7). Climb over bulges (5.7), finish up a 5.8 slab.

The most common descent is to rappel the route. There are typically slung trees for anchors but you'll want to bring your own webbing and rap rings because some of the anchors may be snafflehound-chewed or just plain old and not trustworthy.



Begin just left of the ridge crest, at the Ibex/Steinbok col.

Gear to 3"

Climb the face between the east ridge and southeast ridge for 8 pitches. Join the upper southeast ridge and climb the final 3 pitches of that route to the summit.3 points of aid were used on the FA. Cleaner and steeper than the east ridge.



The face between the E and SE ridges

Full rack.

A granite horn in the Anderson River Range, one of the two most obvious summits from a distance (the other is Steinbok). To the Nlakapamux peoples of the Fraser Canyon, these peaks were known as Tsel-tsel, the Spider Peaks. The south and east faces are steep while the northwestern side is gentler.
